Cudahy Packing Co., 189 Cal. 335 ], and [http://courts.ca.gov/opinions-slip.htm Official Reports Opinions Online] </ref> Basic speed laws are statutized reinforcements of the centuries-old [[common law]] [[negligence]] doctrine as specifically applied to vehicular speed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/clients/CACourts/ |title=Reaugh v. Cudahy Packing Co., 189 Cal. 335 |publisher=Official California Reports, Vol. 189, p. 335, (California Supreme Court reporter) |date=July 27, 1922 |accessdate=July 27, 2013 |quote="This is but a reiteration of the rule, in statutory form, which has always been in force without regard to a statutory promulgation to the effect that drivers or operators of vehicles, and more particularly motor vehicles, must be specially watchful in anticipation of the presence of others at places where other vehicles are constantly passing, and where men, women, and children are liable to be crossing, such as corners at the intersections of streets or other similar places or situations where people are likely to fail to observe an approaching automobile."}}</ref> California Vehicle Code section 22350 is typical; it states that "No person shall drive a vehicle upon a highway at a speed greater than is reasonable ... and in no event at a speed which endangers the safety of persons or property".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d11/vc22350.htm |title=California Vehicle Code section 22350: Basic Speed Law |quote=No person shall drive a vehicle upon a highway at a speed greater than is reasonable or prudent having due regard for weather, visibility, the traffic on, and the surface and width of, the highway, and in no event at a speed which endangers the safety of persons or property. |date=September 20, 1963 |accessdate=April 25, 2010 |publisher=California Department of Motor Vehicles}}</ref>
Speed limits in California are mandated by statute to be set: (1) at or below the 85th [[percentile]] [[operating speed]];<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d11/vc21400.htm |title=California Vehicle Code § 21400(b) |publisher=The State of California |accessdate=July 28, 2013 |date=January 1, 2012 |quote=The Department of Transportation shall revise the California Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, as it read on January 1, 2012, to require the Department of Transportation or a local authority to round speed limits to the nearest five miles per hour of the 85th percentile of the free-flowing traffic. However, in cases in which the speed limit needs to be rounded up to the nearest five miles per hour increment of the 85thpercentile speed, the Department of Transportation or a local authority may decide to instead round down the speed limit to the lower five miles per hour increment, but then the Department of Transportation or a local authority shall not reduce the speed limit any further for any reason.}}</ref> <ref>[http://mutcd.fhwa.dot.gov/htm/2009r1r2/part2/part2b.htm#section2B13 MUTCD Sections 2B.13-16] #12</ref> as determined by a traffic and engineering survey<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d01/vc627.htm |title=CVC § 627 Traffic and Engineering Survey |publisher=CA DMV}}</ref>—this is the speed that no more than 15% of traffic exceeds; or (2) the prima facie limits mandated when certain criteria are met as described in the vehicle code. These criteria include school zone, alleyway, and residential area.<ref name="CA prima facie limits">{{Cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d11/vc22352.htm |title=California Vehicle Code § 22352 Prima Facie Speed Limits |publisher=The State of California |accessdate=July 28, 2013 |date=January 1, 2001}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d11/vc22349.htm |title=California Vehicle Code § 22349 Maximum Speed Limit |publisher=The State of California |accessdate=July 28, 2013 |date=January 1, 2000}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d11/vc22356.htm |title=California Vehicle Code § 22356 Increase of Freeway Speed Limit to 70 Miles Per Hour |publisher=The State of California |accessdate=July 28, 2013 |date=January 7, 1996}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d11/vc22348.htm |title=California Vehicle Code § 22348 Excessive Speed and Designated Lane Use |publisher=The State of California |accessdate=July 28, 2013 |date=January 1, 2005}}</ref><ref name="CA School zone">{{Cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d11/vc22358_4.htm |title=California Vehicle Code § 22358.4 Decrease of Local Limits Near Schools or Senior Centers |publisher=The State of California |accessdate=July 28, 2013 |date=January 1, 2008}}</ref>
If the 85th percentile operating speed as measured by a Traffic and Engineering Survey<ref>[http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d01/vc627.htm Traffic and Engineering Survey]</ref> exceeds the [[design speed]], compulsory legal protection is given to that speed—even if it is unsafe with regard to certain technical aspects such as [[Geometric design of roads#Sight distance|sight distance]]. This speed creep may continue until the 85th percentile operating speed is comparable to speed [[Traffic psychology|psychologically]] perceived as uncomfortably hazardous.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://trb.org/publications/nchrp/nchrp_rpt_504.pdf |title=Design Speed, Operating Speed, and Posted Speed Practice |publisher=Transportation Research Board |page=88 |year=2003 |accessdate=August 29, 2013}}</ref>
The theory behind California's 85th percentile statute is that, as a policy, most of the electorate should be seen as lawful, and limits must be practical to enforce. However, there are some circumstances where motorists do not tend to process all the risks involved, and as a mass choose a poor 85th percentile speed. This rule in substance is a process for voting the speed limit by driving; and in contrast to delegating the speed limit to an engineering expert.{{#tag:ref|Public opposition to speed limits being set by an authority, often arise because such agency has been viewed as abusing its power—such as by arbitrary indiscretion or by creating "speed traps". Because an expert can theoretically calculate a safer speed limit, than the populace's vote by driving, it is beneficial that local governments preserve strong public trust with their integrity in speed regulation. See ''A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets,'' [[American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials|AASHTO]], 4th Ed., 2001; {{ISBN|1-56051-156-7}} |group="Note" |name="Speed limit chosen by the people vs the expert"}}<ref>[http://safety.fhwa.dot.gov/uslimits/ USLIMITS2: A Tool to Aid Practitioners in Determining Appropriate Speed Limit Recommendations]</ref>
The numerical limit set by [[California Department of Transportation|Caltrans]] [[traffic engineering (transportation)|engineers]] for speed limit signs, generally found on all non-[[limited access|controlled-access]] routes, is considered a presumptive maximum "reasonable and prudent" speed.
Many speed limit signs are identified as "maximum speed", usually when the limit is 55 mph (89 km/h) or more. When the [[National Maximum Speed Law]] was enacted, California was forced to create a new legal [[speed limit#Signage|signage]] category, "Maximum Speed", to indicate to drivers that the [[Speed limit#Basic rule: reasonable speed|Basic Speed Law]] did not apply for speeds over the federally mandated speed cap; rather, it would be a violation to exceed the fixed maximum speed indicated on the sign, regardless of whether the driver's speed could be considered "reasonable and prudent".
A driver can receive a [[traffic ticket|traffic citation]] for violating the [[Speed limit#Basic rule: reasonable speed|Basic Speed Law]] even if their speed is below the "maximum speed limit" if road, weather, or traffic conditions make that speed unsafe. However, because the Basic Speed Law establishes ''prima facie'' limits, not absolute ones, they can also defend against a citation for speeding "by competent [[evidence]] that the speed in excess of said limits did not constitute a violation of the basic speed law at the time, place and under the conditions then existing", per section 22351(b) of the California Vehicle Code.<ref>[http://www.dmv.ca.gov/pubs/vctop/d11/vc22351.htm Speed Law Violations California Vehicle Code, section 22351(b)]. Dmv.ca.gov (May 22, 2008).</ref> As attorney David W. Brown says in his book ''Fight Your Ticket & Win in California'', "a person traveling over the speed limit–but less than the usual 65 mph maximum speed (55 mph for two-lane undivided highways)–isn't necessarily violating the law"<ref name="fytaw">{{cite book |title=Fight Your Ticket & Win in California |last=Brown |first=David W. |year=2005 |edition=11th |publisher=[[Nolo.com|Nolo]] |location=Berkeley, CA |isbn=978-1-4133-0641-5 |chapter=Speed Violations and Radar |pages=4/2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5LsenQAACAAJ}}</ref> and that "you can defend against a charge of violating the Basic Speed Law not only by showing you weren't exceeding the speed limit, but also by establishing that even if you were over the limit, your speed was nevertheless 'safe' under the circumstances."<ref name="fytaw"/>{{rp|4–10}}
===Speed limits=== Rural freeways, such as parts of [[Interstate 5 in California|I-5]], [[Interstate 8|I-8]], [[Interstate 10 in California|I-10]], [[Interstate 15 in California|I-15]], [[Interstate 40 in California|I-40]], I-215, I-505, I-580 (between I-205 and I-5), [[U.S. Route 101 in California|U.S. 101]] between [[San Miguel, San Luis Obispo County, California|San Miguel]] and [[King City, California|King City]], and [[California State Route 99|CA 99]] south of [[Madera, California|Madera]] and [[Fresno, California|Fresno]], have {{cvt|70|mph}} speed limits. The highest speed limit on [[Interstate 80 in California|I-80]] is {{cvt|65|mph}} because it passes exclusively through urban and mountainous areas. However, the speed limit on the [[San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge]] and in [[San Francisco]] is only {{cvt|50|mph}}. In downtown Los Angeles, the maximum speed limit is {{cvt|55|mph}}. This includes the entire length of the [[Pasadena Freeway]] between [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]] and downtown Los Angeles, and portions of the [[Hollywood Freeway|Hollywood]], [[Santa Ana Freeway|Santa Ana]], [[Santa Monica Freeway|Santa Monica]], and [[Harbor Freeway]]s. The default limit on 2-lane roads is {{cvt|55|mph}}. However, [[Caltrans]] or a local agency can post a speed of up to {{cvt|65|mph}} after an [[traffic engineering (transportation)|engineering study]].<ref>[http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/waisgate?WAISdocID=9352382531+0+0+0&WAISaction=retrieve WAIS Document Retrieval]. Leginfo.ca.gov.</ref>
There is a {{cvt|55|mph}} speed limit for trucks with 3 or more axles and all vehicles while towing.
In California, the Maximum Speed in [[school zone]]s is {{cvt|15|or|25|mph}}, but may only be in effect when children are present within that school zone.<ref name="CA prima facie limits"/><ref name="CA School zone"/>
==Colorado==
The maximum speed limit in [[Colorado]] is {{cvt|75|mph}} on rural Interstate highways and the toll road portion of [[Colorado State Highway 470|SH 470]] ([[E-470]]), even though [[Interstate 70 in Colorado|Interstate 70]] in the Rocky Mountains has a {{cvt|65|mph}} limit because of steep grades and curves and a {{cvt|50|mph}} limit at the east and west ends of the [[Eisenhower Tunnel]]. The maximum speed limit on other rural highways is {{cvt|65|mph}}.
There are also basic prima facie speed limits in Colorado.<ref name="Establishing Realistic Speed Limits Brochure">[http://www.coloradodot.info/library/Brochures/Establishing_Realistic_Speed_Limits_Brochure.pdf], CDOT Establishing Realistic Speed Limits Brochure.</ref> * {{cvt|20|mph}} on narrow, winding mountain roads * {{cvt|25|mph}} in any business district * {{cvt|30|mph}} in any residential district * {{cvt|40|mph}} on open mountain highways
===Night speed limits=== On certain stretches of rural highways, notably [[U.S. Route 160 in Colorado|US 160]] between [[Durango, Colorado|Durango]] and [[Pagosa Springs, Colorado|Pagosa Springs]] and [[U.S. Route 550 in Colorado|US 550]] between Durango and [[Silverton, Colorado|Silverton]], nighttime speed limits are in effect during peak migratory periods for area wildlife. Speeding fines are doubled when nighttime speed limits are in effect.
==Connecticut== Speed limits in [[Connecticut]] are normally {{cvt|65|mph}} on rural freeways; up to {{cvt|55|mph}} on rural divided and up to {{cvt|50|mph}} on rural undivided highways. In urban areas speed limits vary from {{cvt|25|mph}} on residential streets and central business districts, {{cvt|30 to(-) 40|mph}} on arterial roadways, and from {{cvt|45 to(-) 55|mph}} on urban freeways. [[Limited-access]] [[divided highway]]s have a minimum speed of {{cvt|40|mph}},<ref>[http://www.cga.ct.gov/2005/pub/Chap248.htm#Sec14-220.htm Connecticut General Statutes §14–220] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928163416/http://www.cga.ct.gov/2005/pub/Chap248.htm#Sec14-220.htm |date=September 28, 2011 }}</ref> but this is not always posted, and rarely enforced. Connecticut was among the last states to raise its maximum speed limit from {{cvt|55|mph}} originally established by the [[National Maximum Speed Law]] in 1974. The statewide maximum speed limit was increased from {{cvt|55|mph}} to {{cvt|65|mph}} on October 1, 1998, making Connecticut the last state in the continental United States to raise its speed limit above {{cvt|55|mph}}.
Speed limits for all roads within Connecticut—including local streets—are established by the State Traffic Commission, an agency composed of members of the [[Connecticut Department of Motor Vehicles|Department of Motor Vehicles]] (CTDMV), the [[Connecticut Department of Emergency Services and Public Protection|Department of Emergency Services and Public Protection]] (DESPP), and the [[Connecticut Department of Transportation|Department of Transportation]] (CONNDOT).
The State Traffic Commission typically sets speed limits following engineering studies performed by CONNDOT. Data used in setting speed limits includes traffic volume vs. roadway capacity, design speed, road geometry, the spacing of intersections and/or interchanges, the number of driveways and curb cuts, and accident rates.
Municipalities are normally required to seek approval from the State Traffic Commission for changes to the posted speed limits on locally owned streets after appropriate engineering studies are performed.
Speeding fines are doubled in school zones when children are present, and construction areas when workers are present.
Prior to enactment of the National Speed Limit Law in 1974, Connecticut permitted a maximum speed limit of {{cvt|60|mph}} on rural freeways.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.speed-limits.com/connecticut.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104002458/http://www.speed-limits.com/connecticut.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-11-04|title=Connecticut Speed Limit|date=2016-11-04|access-date=2017-01-07}}</ref>
On March 26, 2018 contractors started installing new speed limit signs on I-84 between the Waterbury/Cheshire line and the interchange with CT Route 9, increasing the speed limit to 65 mph. This action follows a DOT study showing the 85th percentile speed of free flowing traffic on this segment averaged 77 mph.
==Delaware== In [[Delaware]], three roads carry a {{convert|65|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} speed limit: [[Interstate 495 (Delaware)|Interstate 495]], the [[toll road]] portion of [[Delaware Route 1]] and the freeway portion of Route 1 up to exit 160 (US 40), and [[Interstate 95 in Delaware|Interstate 95]] from the Maryland line to the southern junction with I-495. The remainder of [[Interstate 95 (Delaware)|Interstate 95]] between the southern junction with I-495 and the [[Pennsylvania]] line and the freeway portion of [[Delaware Route 141]] are {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} while I-295 is {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. Prior to the National Maximum Speed Law that went into effect nationwide, I-95 used to have a {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} speed limit except around Wilmington.<ref>{{cite web |title=Scrapbook 1969 - 1988 |publisher=Delaware Public Archives |format=PDF |url=http://archives.delaware.gov/exhibits/document/scrapbooks/turnpike3/scrapbook.pdf}}{{page needed|date=December 2015}}</ref> In May 2015, the state of Delaware increased the speed limit on Interstate 95 from {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} to {{convert|65|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} between the Maryland state line and the I-495 interchange.<ref>{{cite news |last=Montgomery |first=Jeff |title=Coming to Delaware's I-95: 65 mph speed limit(this occurred from May 18 to May 21, 2015) |work=The News Journal |location=Wilmington, DE |date=February 25, 2015 |url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/traffic/2015/02/24/delaware-speeds/23953659/ |accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> In January 2017, the speed limit on Delaware Route 1 between Trap Shooters Road and the [[Puncheon Run Connector]] in [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]] was increased from {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} to {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} while the speed limit on the Puncheon Run Connector was increased from {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} to {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite press release|title=TRAFFIC ALERT - State Route 1 and Puncheon Run Connector Speed Limit Increases|publisher=Delaware Department of Transportation|date=January 3, 2017|url=http://www.deldot.gov/home/newsroom/release.shtml?id=6373|accessdate=January 3, 2017}}</ref>
All rural two-lane state-owned roads have {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} speed limits, while all urban speed limits, regardless of location, are held at {{convert|25|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} for two-lane roads and up to {{convert|35|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} for four-lane roads. Four lane highways such as [[U.S. Route 13 in Delaware|US 13]], [[U.S. Route 113|US 113]], portions of [[U.S. Route 40 in Delaware|US 40]] near [[Bear, Delaware|Bear]] and [[Glasgow, Delaware|Glasgow]], and the at-grade portions of DE 1 are normally {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.
[[School zone]]s have {{convert|20|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} speed limits.
[[Interstate 495 (Delaware)|Interstate 495]], which forms a bypass around [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]], features [[variable speed limit]] signs for environmental purposes. These signs typically display a {{convert|65|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} speed limit, but this limit changes to {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on days when [[air quality]] is a concern. The limit is also lowered during construction, weather conditions, and when accidents occur.
All neighborhoods and subdivisions in Delaware have a maximum speed limit of {{convert|25|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} as set by state law. Frequent [[advertising campaigns]] on in-state radio stations remind residents of this (as of January 2013).{{cn|date=January 2018}}
==Florida== Florida has a maximum speed limit of {{cvt|70|mph}}, found on [[Controlled-access highway|freeways]], including rural [[Interstate Highway]]s, some urban freeways including [[Interstate 4|I-4]] in [[Lakeland, Florida|Lakeland]], [[Interstate 75 in Florida|I-75]] in [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] and [[Miami, Florida|Miami]] (where I-75 ends), [[Interstate 95 in Florida|I-95]] near [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]] and from Military Trail to Florida State Route 706 in [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach County]], portions of the [[Orlando]] area Toll Roads such as [[Florida State Road 417|SR 417]] and [[Florida State Road 429|SR 429]], [[Florida's Turnpike]] through [[Port St Lucie]] and Orlando, [[Interstate 10 in Florida|I-10]] close to [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]], and most other rural [[limited access]] [[toll road]]s such as the [[Suncoast Parkway]] and the [[Beachline Expressway]] and rural portions of Florida's Turnpike. {{cvt|65|mph}} is typical on rural 4-lane highways (such as [[U.S. Route 19 in Florida|US-19]] north of [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]], among other [[US Highways]]) as well as most other urban freeways and tollways. Rural two-lane roads typically have a speed limit of {{cvt|55|mph}} (the default limit for such roads), although [[FDOT]] is permitted to post {{cvt|60|mph}} on appropriately-suited highways. This is typically done on very rural state roads (such as [[Florida State Road 471|SR 471]]) and US Highways (such as [[U.S. Route 98 in Florida|US 98]] along most of the state's [[Florida Panhandle|panhandle]]).
Florida typically does not post night speed limits, but there are a few exceptions. For the most part, these night time reduced speeds are located in [[wildlife preserve]]s for such [[endangered species]] as the [[Florida panther]] and the [[key deer]]. Most of the [[Tamiami Trail]] through the [[Big Cypress National Preserve]] has a {{cvt|45|mph}} night speed limit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sherpaguides.com/florida/everglades/tamiami_trail_miami.html |title=Tamiami Trail—Miami to the Western Everglades |accessdate=August 13, 2008}}</ref> On some stretches of road where the speed limit is reduced at night, the daytime speed limit sign is non-reflective, such that at night, only the night limit is visible.
Florida's minimum speed limit on Interstate Highways is {{cvt|50|mph}} in 70 mph zones. In 55 mph, and 65 mph urban interstate zones, the minimum is {{cvt|40|mph}}. At one time, these minimum speeds required signage, but these limits have since been codified in state law; signs indicating these minimum speeds still exist, but now simply serve as a reminder.<ref>[http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0300-0399/0316/Sections/0316.183.html Statutes & Constitution :View Statutes : Online Sunshine]. Leg.state.fl.us.</ref> Urban freeways with speed limits of 50 mph typically do not have minimum speed limits, such as on [[Interstate 375 (Florida)|I-375]] in [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]]. Additionally, the new [[Gandy Freeway]] in St Petersburg has a speed limit as low as {{cvt|45|mph}}.
Florida also does not impose lower truck speed limits. As such, all traffic is permitted to travel at the same speed.<ref name="Florida Motorist Information">{{cite web |title=Florida Motorist Information |url=http://www.motorists.org/chapters/florida |publisher=National Motorists Association}}</ref>
[[School zone]]s in Florida usually have {{cvt|10-20|mph}} limits. Most have flashing yellow lights activated during the times they are in effect as well as accompanying signs that post the times these reduced speed limits are effective. All are strictly enforced and carry an increased penalty for violations.
==Georgia== Rural [[List of Interstate Highways in Georgia (U.S. state)|Interstate Highways]] are posted at {{cvt|70|mph}}. Until 2014, sections of Interstates passing through a municipality or metropolitan area with a population over fifty thousand were capped at {{cvt|55-65|mph}}. However, a new law has permitted urban interstates to now be posted as high as 70 mph,<ref>{{cite news |date=May 29, 2014 |title=New Georgia laws could bump up urban speeds, limit left lane use |author=Keith Goble |work=Land Line |url=http://www.landlinemag.com/Story.aspx?StoryID=27097}}</ref> and some have already reflected this change, such as [[Interstate 95 in Georgia|I-95]] through [[Brunswick, Georgia|Brunswick]], [[Interstate 85 in Georgia|I-85]] in [[Gwinnett County, Georgia|Gwinnett County]], and [[Interstate 75 in Georgia|I-75]] in [[Macon, Georgia|Macon]], [[Valdosta, Georgia|Valdosta]], and [[Tifton, Georgia|Tifton]]. Most urban interstates, however, still remain at or below 65 mph. [[Interstate 285 in Georgia|I-285]] in the [[Atlanta metropolitan area|Atlanta area]] was recently increased from {{cvt|55|mph}} to {{cvt|65|mph}} (with [[Variable speed limit]]s on the north portion). I-95 and [[Interstate 16 in Georgia|I-16]] through suburban [[Savannah, Georgia|Savannah]] (the 65 mph limit on I-95 is only for a 1.5 mile section in the vicinity of the I-16 interchange), I-16 from the interchange with [[Interstate 75 in Georgia|I-75]] in central [[Macon, Georgia|Macon]] eastbound past Exit 2 is at 65 mph, and [[Interstate 185 in Georgia|I-185]] in [[Columbus, Georgia|Columbus]] remain at 65 mph, while the [[Downtown Connector]] and portions of [[Interstate 20 in Georgia|I-20]] in [[Atlanta]] are posted as low as {{cvt|50|mph}}. Most non-interstate freeways such as [[Georgia State Route 400|SR 400]] and the [[Athens, Georgia|Athens]] perimeter highway, are posted at 55 to 65 mph.
Four lane arterials and expressways can be posted as high as {{cvt|65|mph}}. However, [[John Forrest Dillon|Dillon's Rule]] enables counties outside municipalities to keep four-lane GRIP corridors at {{cvt|55|mph}}. However, in recent years, [[U.S. Route 1 in Georgia|US 1]] between Augusta and Wrens raised the speed limit to 65 mph. Other rural four-lane highways with a 65 mph include portions of [[U.S. Route 441 in Georgia|US 441]] near [[Irwinton, Georgia|Irwinton]], [[U.S. Route 25 in Georgia|US 25]] between [[Augusta, Georgia|Augusta]] and [[Statesboro, Georgia|Statesboro]], [[Georgia State Route 88|SR 88]] between [[Sandersville, Georgia|Sandersville]] and [[Wrens, Georgia|Wrens]], [[Georgia State Route 16|SR 16]] between [[Griffin, Georgia|Griffin]] and I-75, much of [[U.S. Route 341 in Georgia|US 341]] between [[Brunswick, Georgia|Brunswick]] and I-75, and much of [[U.S. Route 82 in Georgia|US 82]] in South Georgia.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
Two lane state roads by default are posted at {{cvt|55|mph}}. County maintained roads will rarely have speed limits above {{cvt|50|mph}} in middle & south Georgia, {{cvt|45|mph}} in north Georgia. Both in the Atlanta area, [[Ronald Reagan Parkway]] is posted at {{cvt|50|mph}} as a county maintained freeway and [[Sugarloaf Parkway]] is posted at {{cvt|55|mph}} along its new eastern freeway portion.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
Inside the municipality, speed limits are generally posted at {{cvt|35|mph}} while it is {{cvt|25–30|mph}} in the downtown area.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
All roadways maintained by GDOT that are subject to speed limit reductions are given advanced notice with signage that says "REDUCED SPEED AHEAD". Furthermore, GDOT has a policy of doing {{cvt|5-10|mph}} increments but never higher than 10 mph.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
Georgia is one of few states with anti-speed trap laws passed in the late 1990s. Speed violations less than {{cvt|15|mph}} over the speed limit will have no points assessed.<ref>[http://www.dds.ga.gov/drivers/DLdata.aspx?con=1749471757&ty=dl Points and Points Reduction] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814060529/http://www.dds.ga.gov/drivers/DLdata.aspx?con=1749471757&ty=dl# |date=August 14, 2014 }}. Dds.ga.gov (October 4, 2012).</ref> Fines are not assessed for motorists going less than {{cvt|10|mph}} over the speed limit. In 2009, Georgia introduced the "Super Speeder" law, which adds an additional speeding fine of $200 for motorists convicted of traveling {{cvt|75|mph}} or more on a two-lane or undivided road and {{cvt|85|mph}} or more on a divided highway.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
==Guam==
The speed limit in [[Guam]] is 45 mph (72 km/h), with 35-45 mph (56-72 km/h) in undivided rural areas and 35 mph (56 km/h) in rural areas.<ref>http://www.justice.gov.gu/compileroflaws/GCA/16gca/16gc003.PDF {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325115518/http://www.justice.gov.gu/compileroflaws/GCA/16gca/16gc003.PDF# |date=March 25, 2009 }} ''Justice.gov.gu.'' Retrieved 8 January 2018.</ref>
==Hawaii== Hawaii was the last state to raise its maximum speed limit after the [[National Maximum Speed Law]] was repealed in 1995, and still has the lowest maximum speed limit of any state. In 2002, following public outcry after a controversial experiment with [[speed limit#Enforcement|speed enforcement]] using [[traffic enforcement camera]]s, the state [[Hawaii Department of Transportation|Department of Transportation]] raised the speed limit to {{cvt|60|mph}} on [[Interstate H-1]] between [[Kapolei, Hawaii|Kapolei]] and [[Waipahu, Hawaii|Waipahu]], and [[Interstate H-3]] between the [[Tetsuo Harano Tunnels]] and the junction with H-1.<ref>{{cite news |author=Rod Antone |title=State approves higher speed limits |url=http://starbulletin.com/2002/04/18/news/story5.html |newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin |date=April 18, 2002}}</ref> All other freeways, including [[Interstate H-2]], have a maximum speed limit of {{cvt|55|mph}}, with the limit dropping to {{cvt|45|mph}} in central [[Honolulu]]. Other highways generally have speed limits of 55 mph and in many cases much less.<ref>[http://www.hawaiihighways.com/FAQs-page2.htm#speed-limit FAQs page 2]. Hawaii Highways.</ref> On July 6, 2016, Governor David Ige has signed a bill to allow the Speed Limit on Saddle Road to increase from 55 mph to 60 mph (the limit was increased to 60 mph the week of February 5, 2017).<ref>http://hawaiitribune-herald.com/news/local-news/ige-ok-s-higher-speed-limit-saddle-road</ref>
Hawaii has a minimum speed along much of [[Interstate H-1]] of only {{cvt|10|mph}} below the speed limit. The minimum speed is usually {{cvt|45|mph}} when the speed limit is 55, and {{cvt|40|mph}} when the speed limit is 50.
==Idaho==
The speed limit on a freeway in Idaho is generally {{cvt|80|mph}} in rural areas and {{cvt|65|mph}} in urban areas. Trucks are limited to {{cvt|70|mph}}. Generally, both single- and multi-lane rural roads have {{cvt|70|mph}} limits. Roads with traffic lights are posted at {{cvt|60|mph}} or below. The school zone speed limit in Idaho is {{cvt|20|mph}}.
Idaho senator [[Bart Davis]] brought SB 1284a to the [[Idaho House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] for discussion in early 2014. The bill passed the [[Idaho Senate|Senate]] on February 25 and was signed into law by Governor [[Butch Otter]] on March 18, 2014, which was set to raise the speed limit on rural interstates to {{cvt|80|mph}} on July 1, 2014, the same date [[Wyoming]] raised its speed limit. Days before the law was to go into effect, however, it was put on hold in order to allow a more thorough review of the effects of a raised speed limit.<ref name="New speed">{{cite web |title=80 mph speed limit law delayed |url=http://www.kboi2.com/news/local/Idaho-Speed-Limit-264926731.html |publisher=KBOI |accessdate=July 14, 2014}}</ref> A vote on July 14, 2014 approved the 80 mph increase on limited sections of interstates in the southern portions of Idaho. Studies will begin for other areas later of that summer.<ref name="80 in effect">{{cite news |title=Transportation Board OKs 80 Mph for Idaho Freeways |url=http://magicvalley.com/news/local/transportation-board-oks-mph-for-s-idaho-freeway-stretches-that/article_abe851ca-0b81-11e4-b6ef-001a4bcf887a.html |newspaper=Twin Falls Times-News |accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> The bill also would raise truck and two-lane highway speed limits to {{cvt|70|mph}}.<ref name="80 passes">{{cite news |title=80 mph speed limit bill clears House panel |url=http://www.spokesman.com/blogs/boise/2014/mar/04/80-mph-speed-limit-bill-clears-house-panel/ |newspaper=The Spokesman Review |accessdate=March 4, 2014}}</ref> As of July 24, 2014, the new 80 mph signs are up on rural Idaho Interstates.<ref>{{cite news |title=Speed limit now 80 mph on some Idaho interstates |publisher=KTVB-TV |location=Boise, ID |date=July 24, 2014 |url=http://www.ktvb.com/story/news/local/2014/07/24/speed-limit-increases/13103293/ |accessdate=July 25, 2014}}</ref>
On March 22, 2017 the speed limit on a four-lane, divided stretch of [[U.S. Route 20 in Idaho|US 20]] between [[Idaho Falls, Idaho|Idaho Falls]] and [[Ashton, Idaho|Ashton]] was raised from {{cvt|65|mph}} to 70 mph.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Post Register|url=http://www.postregister.com/articles/news-daily-email-todays-headlines/2017/03/20/speed-limit-raises-70-mph-us-20-stretch#|last=Johnson|first=Lindsey|title=Speed limit raises to 70 mph on U.S. 20 stretch|date=March 20, 2017|accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Clearwater Tribune|url=http://www.clearwatertribune.com/news/online_only_news/speed-limit-on-section-of-u-s-increases-to-mph/article_b1a93c8a-0d92-11e7-adc7-27412fd5c40e.html|title=Speed limit on section of U.S. 20 increases Wednesday|date=March 20, 2017|accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.localnews8.com/news/speed-limit-changes/404486981|publisher=Local News 8|title=ITD changing Hwy. 20 speed limit this week|last=Kassahun|first=Pheben|date=March 20, 2017|accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref>
==Illinois== [[Interstate Highway]]s in [[Illinois]] are usually posted with both minimum and maximum speed limits, except in some urban areas, particularly Chicago. The standard speed limit is 70 mph for rural freeways, a 45 mph minimum speed limit, 65 mph for other 4 lane divided highways, and 55 mph for all other highways. Urban freeway/interstate speed limits can range from as low as 45 mph in downtown Chicago, where all the major interstates merge, to as high as 65 mph in the outer portions of the Chicago metro and East St. Louis metro areas, and in some smaller cities. Some interstates in small cities (e.g. I-55/74 through Bloomington-Normal, I-39/90 through the Rockford area, I-57 & I-74 through Champaign-Urbana) do not have reduced speed limits, and a stretch of I-355 between I-55 and I-80 in the southwest suburbs of Chicago is signed at 70 mph. Most freeways and interstates in [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook]], [[DuPage County, Illinois|DuPage]], and [[Lake County, Illinois|Lake]] Counties, and some interstates and freeways in [[Will County, Illinois|Will County]] maintain a 55-60 mph speed limit.<ref>{{cite web |title=Public Act 098-1126 |publisher=Illinois General Assembly |url=http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/publicacts/fulltext.asp?Name=098-1126 |date=January 1, 2015}}</ref> Due to the high population density, the only freeways in Cook County that exceed a speed limit of 60 mph are [[Interstate 57 in Illinois|I-57]] at the southern edge of the county, part of [[Interstate 80|I-80]] between Central Ave and Harlem Ave, and the southern segment of [[Interstate 355|I-355]], which passes through Cook County briefly before crossing into Will County to both the north and south. As of January 2010, a reduced speed limit posted in a construction zone must be obeyed 24 hours a day, regardless of whether workers are present.<ref>IL DOT Fact Sheet. http://www.dot.state.il.us/safetyEng/FactSheet-Rev-3-29-2010-Final1.pdf</ref>
On February 10, 2017, a bill was introduced to raise the speed limit on select rural interstate freeways and highways to 75 mph. The bill also contains a provision to increase maximum speed limits to 60 mph for all rural highways, roads, and streets that do not have 4 or more lanes of traffic. This bill and one filed in 2018 died in the legislature.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=WQAD News 8|title=Proposed Illinois law looking to raise speed limit on interstates|last=Hepner|first=Christina|url=http://wqad.com/2017/02/19/proposed-illinois-law-looking-to-raise-speed-limit-on-interstates/|date=February 19, 2017|accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bill Status of SB2036|url=http://ilga.gov/legislation/BillStatus.asp?GA=100&DocTypeID=SB&DocNum=2036&GAID=14&SessionID=91&LegID=105516|website=Illinois General Assembly|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}</ref> As of March 27, 2018, the speed limit on I-90 from Randall Rd. in Elgin to Mt. Prospect Rd. in Des Plaines has been increased to 70 mph, and from Mt. Prospect Rd. to the beginning of the Kennedy Expressway, it has been increased to 60 mph <ref>{{cite web |last1=Wisniewski |first1=Mary |title=Tollway increases speed limit to 70 mph on I-90 in northwest suburbs |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-met-speed-limits-tollway-20180403-story.html |website=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref>. I-290 is posted at 60 mph for a few miles near Schaumburg, from IL-72 down to shortly before the I-355 exit.
==Indiana== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2018}} In [[Indiana]] speed limits on [[Interstate Highway]]s are usually {{cvt|70|mph|0}} for cars and {{cvt|65|mph|0}} for trucks with a [[gross weight|gross vehicular weight (GVW)]] of {{convert|26000|lb}} or greater. In urban areas, it is generally {{cvt|55|mph|0}}, except stretches of [[Interstate 70 (Indiana)|Interstate 70]] in [[Indianapolis]] where it is {{cvt|50|mph|0}}. In suburban areas, it is {{cvt|65|mph|0}} for cars and {{cvt|60|mph|0}} for trucks.
Most non-Interstate Highways are {{cvt|55|mph|0}}, but some rural four-lane [[divided highway]]s are set at {{cvt|60|mph|0}}. These limits often decrease to {{cvt|30|-|50|mph|0}} approaching urban areas, and within cities a speed limit of {{cvt|20|-|30|mph|0}} is not uncommon, though larger [[arterial road]]s within cities may reach as high as {{cvt|45|mph|0}}. On February 6, 2012 the Indiana toll road was raised from the Illinois state line to mile marker 20 to {{cvt|70|mph|0}} after a major highway reconstruction project.
==Iowa== In [[Iowa]], the majority of highways have a {{convert|55|mph|abbr=on|adj=on|round=5}} speed limit. Rural Interstate Highways carry a {{convert|70|mph|abbr=on|adj=on|round=5}} limit and a {{convert|40|mph|abbr=on|adj=on|round=5}} minimum. Urban Interstate limits generally range from {{convert|55|to|65|mph|abbr=on|round=5}}, but may be lower in areas. The [[Interstate 74 Bridge]] from [[Bettendorf, Iowa|Bettendorf]] to [[Moline, Illinois]], for instance, has a {{convert|50|mph|abbr=on|adj=on|round=5}} limit because the bridge is narrow and has no shoulders. Four-lane roads may have a {{convert|65|mph|abbr=on|adj=on|round=5}} limit. If the road is built to [[Interstate Highway standards|freeway standards]], such as [[U.S. Highway 20 in Iowa|US 20]] between [[Interstate 35 in Iowa|I-35]] and [[Dubuque, Iowa|Dubuque]], it may have a minimum speed limit, but otherwise four-lane roads carry no minimum limit so slow-moving farm vehicles may use the roadway.
On February 21, 2017, a bill was introduced to raise speed limits from 70 mph to 75 mph on interstate freeways, however it was not enacted.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mitchell|first=Scimidt|title=Measure would raise Iowa interstate speed limit to 75 mph|url=http://www.thegazette.com/subject/news/government/bill-aims-to-raise-iowa-interstate-speed-limit-to-75-mph-20170221|publisher=The Gazette|date=February 21, 2017|accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref>
==Kansas== After the National Maximum Speed Limit was repealed, [[Kansas]] raised its general interstate speed limit to {{Convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}; a study found "no statistically significant increases in crash, fatal crash and fatality rates were noted during the after period on either rural or urban interstate highway networks. On the other hand, statistically significant increases in crash, fatal crash and fatality rates were observed on the 2-lane rural highway network.".<ref>[http://ntl.bts.gov/lib/11000/11100/11138/KSU983.pdf Text-i-ii-pages.PDF]. (PDF).</ref> In 2011 Governor [[Sam Brownback]] signed legislation raising Kansas' top speed limit to {{Convert|75|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on Rural Interstates and limited access portions of U.S. Routes, effective July 1, 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Top Kansas Speed Limit Rising |date=April 20, 2011 |newspaper=The Wichita Eagle |url=http://www.kansas.com/2011/04/20/1815851/top-kansas-speed-limit-rising.html }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The [[Kansas Department of Transportation]] announced on June 21, 2011, that 807 miles of roadway, comprising the rural areas of I-70, I-35, I-135, the [[Kansas Turnpike]] and the freeway-improved sections of US-69 and US-81, will be raised to 75 mph.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Kansas routes designated for 75 mph speed limit |date=June 21, 2011 |publisher=Kansas Department of Transportation |url=http://www.ksdot.org/PDF_Files/Kansas-routes-designated-for-75-mph-speed-limit.pdf}}</ref> Other four-lane, non-limited access divided highways have a speed limit of 70 mph, with 65 mph on two-lane undivided roads, and 55 mph on township roads. Prior to the National Maximum Speed Limit, the speed limit on the Kansas Turnpike used to be {{Convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, but was reduced to 75 mph on August 17, 1970. The minimum speed limit on Kansas Interstates is 40 mph.
==Kentucky== [[Kentucky]] generally has a 70 mph speed limit on rural freeways as of 2007. The speed limit is reduced to 55 on multi-lane highways in some urban areas (I-71/[[Interstate 75 in Kentucky|75]] south of [[Cincinnati]], [[Interstate 64 in Kentucky|I-64]], [[Interstate 65 in Kentucky|I-65]], [[Interstate 71|I-71]] and [[Interstate 264 (Kentucky)|I-264]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], and [[KY 4]] in Lexington. There are two 50 mph areas in Louisville. One approaching the [[Sherman Minton Bridge]] crossing the [[Ohio River]] into [[Indiana]] on I-64, and one approaching the [[John F. Kennedy Memorial Bridge|Kennedy Bridge]] on I-65 towards [[Indiana]]. The Transportation Cabinet is now authorized to raise any multilane, divided rural highway up to 65 MPH based on speed and design studies. Anyone may request an increase by contacting their local Transportation Cabinet office and specifying the roadway to be raised. Two-lane, undivided highways are limited to 55 MPH. Points are not assessed for speeds less than 10 mph over the speed limit only on limited access highways, or for tickets received by Kentucky licensed drivers out of state.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kentucky Driver Manual |url=http://www.kentuckystatepolice.org/pdf/2011_ky_drivers_manual.pdf}}{{page needed|date=December 2015}}</ref>
==Louisiana== Louisiana's highest speed limit is 75 mph, found on 154 miles of [[Interstate 49]] in [[Saint Landry Parish|Saint Landry]], [[Avoyelles Parish|Avoyelles]], [[Evangeline Parish|Evangeline]], [[Rapides Parish|Rapides]], [[Natchitoches Parish|Natchitoches]], [[DeSoto Parish|DeSoto]] and [[Caddo Parish|Caddo]] parishes. The 75 zone was established by the [[Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development]] in 2011 after a 2010 bill authorized the DOTD to implement 75 zones where proven to be safe.<ref>[http://theadvocate.com/news/340351-64/i-49-speed-limit-increased-to.html The Advocate: I-49 speed limit increased to 75 mph] Retrieved September 14, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.nola.com/newsflash/index.ssf/story/i-49-speed-limit-increased-to-75-mph/57952c5f3dbc4344b638be40f8e71c9b nola.com: Interstate 49 speed limit increased to 75 mph between central, north Louisiana] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019134309/http://www.nola.com/newsflash/index.ssf/story/i-49-speed-limit-increased-to-75-mph/57952c5f3dbc4344b638be40f8e71c9b# |date=October 19, 2012 }} Posted July 11, 2011; retrieved 2011-09-14.</ref><ref>[http://www.dotd.la.gov/pressreleases/release.aspx?key=1666 La. DOTD: DOTD announces speed limit increase along I-49 in DeSoto Parish] Retrieved April 13, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.dotd.la.gov/pressreleases/release.aspx?key=1669 La. DOTD: DOTD announces speed limit increase along I-49 in Avoyelles, Natchitoches and Rapides parishes] Retrieved September 14, 2011.</ref>
70 mph is posted on Interstates [[Interstate 10 in Louisiana|10]], [[Interstate 12|12]], [[Interstate 20 in Louisiana|20]], [[Interstate 49 in Louisiana|49]], [[Interstate 55 in Louisiana|55]], [[Interstate 59 in Louisiana|59]], [[Interstate 220 (Louisiana)|220]], and [[Interstate 310 (Louisiana)|310]].
A speed limit of 60 mph is posted on I-10 in [[Lake Charles, Louisiana|Lake Charles]], [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], and from [[LaPlace, Louisiana|LaPlace]] to [[New Orleans]], I-12 in Baton Rouge, I-20 in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]] and [[Monroe, Louisiana|Monroe]], I-49 in [[Alexandria, Louisiana|Alexandria]] and Shreveport, I-310 in [[Destrehan, Louisiana|Destrehan]], I-220 in Shreveport, U.S. Routes [[U.S. Route 71|71]] and [[U.S. Route 167|167]] in [[Kingsville, Louisiana|Kingsville]], [[LA 3132]], and Interstates [[Interstate 110 (Louisiana)|110]], [[Interstate 210 (Louisiana)|210]], [[Interstate 510 (Louisiana)|510]], [[Interstate 610 (Louisiana)|610]], and [[Interstate 910 (Louisiana)|910]] (note: part of I-10 in Baton Rouge was raised to 70 mph, and part of I-12 in Baton Rouge was also raised to 65 mph).
Most two-lane highways in Louisiana have a maximum speed limit of 55 mph.
In August 2003, [[Murphy J. Foster, Jr.|Governor Mike Foster]] announced speed and lane restrictions on trucks on the 18 mile (29 km) stretch of [[Interstate 10]] known as the [[Atchafalaya Swamp Freeway]]. The restrictions lower the truck speed limit to 55 mph and restrict them to the right lane for the entire length of the elevated freeway.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20061210110628/http://www.dps.state.la.us/tiger/lowerspdlimitsandlaneresttrucksI10.htm Lower Speed Limits and Lane Restrictions for Trucks on I-10 over Atchafalaya Basin]</ref>
===Other laws=== There are exceptions to the basic highway and speed laws<ref>[http://www.nhtsa.gov/people/injury/enforce/speedlaws501/toc/laspeed.pdf] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140507042656/http://www.nhtsa.gov/people/injury/enforce/speedlaws501/toc/laspeed.pdf# |date=May 7, 2014 }} -Louisiana divided highway speed limit.</ref>
Divided highways in rural areas have a 65 mph speed limits. Louisiana law R.S. 32:61(B) & 32:62(A) states;<blockquote>65 mph on other multi-lane divided highways which have partial or no control of access.</blockquote>
Louisiana operates under the reasonable and prudent basic law;<blockquote>No person shall drive a vehicle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and potential hazards then existing, having due regard for the traffic on, and the surface and width of, the highway, and the condition of the weather. R.S. 32:64(A)</blockquote>
A person, who is operating a motor vehicle on a multilane highway at less than the normal speed of traffic, shall drive in the right-hand lane then available for traffic. R.S. 32:71(B)(1)
==Maine== Maine carries the highest speed limit on the East Coast, with [[Interstate 95 in Maine|Interstate 95]] carrying a 75 mph limit between [[Old Town, Maine|Old Town]] and [[Houlton, Maine|Houlton]]. Sections of I-95 south of Old Town as well as [[Interstate 295 (Maine)|295]] carry 70 mph limits, except for brief 50-65 zones in more populated areas (NOTE: the speed limit on I-295 was recently restored to 65 mph between Falmouth and Topsham as of March 27, 2017). The [[Saco, Maine|Saco]] stub [[Interstate 195 (Maine)|I-195]] is 60 mph, and [[Interstate 395 (Maine)|I-395]] is 60 mph in [[Bangor, Maine|Bangor]] and 65 mph in [[Brewer, Maine|Brewer]].{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
Default speed limits in Maine are: * 20 mph in a school zone within 30 minutes of the beginning or end of a school day, or during recess * 20 mph near an intersection "when the operator's view is obstructed", unless [[right-of-way]] is given via signage * 25 mph in business or residential districts, or other built-up areas * 45 mph on other roads
In Maine, [[School Bus|school buses]] may not exceed 45 mph on roads with higher speed limits while transporting students. At other times, the limit is 55 mph, unless on an [[Interstate highway]], in which case the posted limit applies.
Also the speed limit on county road is 30 MPH Fines for speeding are at least $50 by law. Exceeding the speed limit by 30 mph or more is considered a [[criminal offense]]. <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mainelegislature.org/legis/statutes/29-a/title29-asec2074.html | title = Title 29-A, §2074: Rates of speed | last = | first = | date = 1993–2009 | website = [[Maine Legislature]] Revised Statutes | publisher = Office of the Revisor of Statutes | access-date = August 28, 2016 | quote = }}</ref>
==Maryland== The speed limit on [[Maryland]]'s Interstate Highways are posted by default at 65 mph although 70 mph limits can be posted after a traffic and engineering study. Effective October 1, 2015 the speed limit on [[Interstate 68|I-68]] is 70 mph except for a seven-mile section around [[Cumberland, Maryland|Cumberland]]. Effective April 4, 2016, the speed limit on [[Interstate 70 in Maryland|I-70]] has been increased to 70 mph from the [[Pennsylvania]] state line to [[Maryland Route 180|MD 180]] in [[Frederick County, Maryland|Frederick County]] and from [[Maryland Route 144|MD 144]] in Frederick County to [[U.S. Route 29 in Maryland|US 29]] in [[Howard County, Maryland|Howard County]].<ref name=wbal>{{cite news|title=Speed limit increases to 70 mph on parts of I-70|publisher=WBAL-TV|location=Baltimore, MD|date=April 4, 2016|url=http://www.wbaltv.com/news/speed-limit-increases-to-70-mph-on-parts-of-i70/38856414|accessdate=April 4, 2016}}</ref> Maryland's urban freeways normally have speed limits of 55 mph (like [[Interstate 495 (Capital Beltway)|I-495]]) or 60 mph, although some stretches are signed for 65 mph travel such as portions of [[Interstate 95 in Maryland|I-95]] and [[Interstate 97|I-97]] in and around the [[Baltimore]] suburbs, I-70 around Frederick, and I-81 around Hagerstown. I-70 around Hagerstown is posted at 70 mph. More restrictive limits are found on [[Interstate 83|I-83]] south of [[North Avenue (Baltimore)|North Avenue]] when approaching [[downtown Baltimore]] and on I-68 through Cumberland, both sections being marked at 40 mph.
Four lane non-interstates and non-freeways are posted at 55 mph. This includes the expressway grade roadways like [[U.S. Route 50 in Maryland|US 50]] and [[U.S. Route 301 in Maryland|US 301]] east of the [[Chesapeake Bay Bridge|Bay Bridge]], [[U.S. Route 15 in Maryland|US 15]] north of Frederick to the Pennsylvania state line, [[Maryland Route 404|MD 404]] around [[Denton, Maryland|Denton]] and US 29 between I-495 and I-70.
Normally, speed limit drops are in 5 mph to 10 mph increments. However, one speed zone drops from 55 to 25 mph along US 301 southbound at the [[Nice Bridge]] for the toll plaza.
Two lane roads are generally posted at 50 mph but there are a handful of routes posted at 55 mph. It is more common to see 55 mph on the [[Eastern Shore of Maryland|Eastern Shore]] and in Frederick and [[Carroll County, Maryland|Carroll]] counties than the [[Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area|Baltimore-Washington corridor]] and [[Western Maryland]]. Two lane routes that have a speed limit of 55 mph enforce mandatory headlight use.
Urban and downtown speed limits are generally posted at 30 mph.
==Massachusetts== As prescribed by Massachusetts law,<ref>{{M.G.L.|90|17}}</ref> default speed limits are the following:
*{{convert|15|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in the area of a vehicle (for example, an ice cream truck) that is selling merchandise and is displaying flashing amber lights *{{convert|20|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in a school zone when children are present *{{convert|30|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on a road in a "thickly settled" or business district for at least {{convert|1/8|mi|m}} *{{convert|40|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on a road outside of a "thickly settled" or business district for at least {{convert|1/4|mi|m}} *{{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on a divided highway outside of a "thickly settled" or business district for at least {{convert|1/4|mi|m}}
State highways and other arterials are often posted at {{cvt|35 to(-) 40|mph}} in urban areas and {{cvt|45 to(-) 50|mph}} in rural areas. A select number of undivided roads are posted at {{cvt|55|mph}}. Divided highways are usually posted at {{cvt|45 to(-) 55|mph}} in rural areas as well as business districts. [[List of Interstate Highways in Massachusetts|Interstate highways]] and some non-Interstate [[controlled-access highway]]s in suburban and rural areas are posted at {{cvt|65|mph}}, but many non-Interstate highways are posted at {{cvt|55|mph}}, such as the freeway portions of [[U.S. Route 3 in Massachusetts|US 3]], [[U.S. Route 6 in Massachusetts|US 6]], [[Massachusetts Route 2|Route 2]], and [[Massachusetts Route 128|Route 128]], or {{cvt|60|mph}}, such as [[Massachusetts Route 3]] South of Boston. Urban freeways are often posted at {{cvt|55|mph}} and occasionally lower, but some rural freeways that pass through urban areas maintain their {{cvt|65|mph}} speed limit, such as the [[Massachusetts Turnpike]] through the [[Springfield, Massachusetts|Springfield]] and [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]] areas.<ref>{{cite map|last=Carr|first=John|title=Map of Massachusetts speed limits|url=http://www.mit.edu/~jfc/maps/speed/Speed-Limits.gif|format=GIF}}</ref>
A "thickly settled district" is an area where building structures such as residential and commercial are less than {{convert|200|ft|m}} apart for a distance of {{convert|1|mi|km}} or more. This can be subjective since a large part of eastern Massachusetts is built up with many different jurisdictions and different speed limits assigned.
==Michigan== The maximum speed limit in [[Michigan]] is {{cvt|75|mph}}. Michigan uses a formula based on the number of driveways and streets, or on the 85th percentile of free-flowing traffic, and if none those methods are used a {{cvt|55|mph}} default applies.<ref>{{cite web |title=NMA Michigan |url=http://blog.motorists.org/how-to-fight-a-michigan-speeding-ticket/ |publisher=National Motorist Association |accessdate=July 18, 2011}}</ref> In rural areas, speed limits are as follows:
* Freeway speeds for passenger vehicles range from {{cvt|70|mph}} to {{cvt|75|mph}}. * Freeway speeds for trucks and military vehicles is {{cvt|65|mph}}. * Non-freeway speeds for passenger vehicles and trucks range from {{cvt|55|mph}} to {{cvt|65|mph}}.
Freeways in Michigan are usually signed with both minimum and maximum speeds. By default, the freeway speed limit is {{cvt|70|mph}}, with a minimum speed of {{cvt|55|mph}} for all vehicles, despite a truck speed limit of {{cvt|65|mph}}—effectively permitting trucks only a {{cvt|10|mph}} range of legal speeds.<ref name=MI300.1949.IV>{{cite web |url=http://www.legislature.mi.gov/(S(s241gx553frlpfjo2guswzuf))/mileg.aspx?page=getObject&objectName=mcl-300-1949-VI-SPEED-RESTRICTIONS |title=Public Michigan Vehicle code: Speed Restrictions |date=November 9, 2006 |accessdate=April 30, 2007 |work=Michigan Legislature}}</ref> The [[Mackinac Bridge]], due to its substandard design, has a speed limit of {{cvt|45|mph}} for passenger vehicles and {{cvt|20|mph}} for trucks. The [[Michigan Department of Transportation]] and the [[Michigan State Police]] may raise the speed limit to {{cvt|75|mph}} after it is deemed safe to do so.<ref name="mlive.com">http://www.mlive.com/news/index.ssf/2016/06/state_house_approves_75_mph_sp.html</ref> MDOT and the MSP announced on April 26, 2017 that the speed limit was increased to 75 mph on several Michigan freeways, including [[Interstate 75 in Michigan|I-75]] from [[Bay City, Michigan|Bay City]] to [[Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan|Sault Ste. Marie]] (excluding the [[Mackinac Bridge]]), [[Interstate 69 in Michigan|I-69]] from Business Loop 69 in [[Clinton County, Michigan|Clinton County]] to I-94 in [[St. Clair County, Michigan|St. Clair County]] (excluding the section in and around [[Flint, Michigan|Flint]], which remains at {{cvt|70|mph}}), [[U.S. Route 127 in Michigan|US 127]] from I-69 in [[Clinton County, Michigan|Clinton County]] to I-75 in [[Crawford County, Michigan|Crawford County]] (excluding the 15-mile stretch between [[St. Johns, Michigan|St. Johns]] and [[Ithaca, Michigan|Ithaca]], which is not freeway standard), and [[US Route 131|US 131]] from [[M-57 (Michigan highway)|M-57]] in [[Kent County, Michigan|Kent County]] to the end of the freeway north of [[Manton, Michigan|Manton]]. These increases commenced on May 1, 2017 and were completed by May 15, 2017. Speed limits in freeway work zones are statutorily limited to {{cvt|60|mph}} 24 hours per day. If workers are present (and not behind a barrier wall), drivers must slow to {{cvt|45|mph}} for the workers' safety.
Michigan's speed limits on urban Interstates are typically higher than its neighboring states. For example, in the Detroit metro area, [[Interstate 75 in Michigan|I-75]] southbound enters Detroit at [[M-102 (Michigan highway)|M-102]] (8 Mile Road, exit 59) and maintains a {{cvt|70|mph}} limit all the way until the interchange with [[Interstate 94 in Michigan|I-94]] (exit 53), where the speed limit drops to {{cvt|55|mph}}. Other freeways in Detroit such as [[Interstate 94 in Michigan|I-94]] and [[Interstate 96|I-96]] also have {{cvt|55|mph}} speed limits in and around the city's downtown area, but rise to {{cvt|70|mph}} relatively soon after leaving the downtown area. In Downtown [[Grand Rapids, Michigan|Grand Rapids]], [[Interstate 196|I-196]] has a speed limit of {{cvt|65|mph}}, the only other urban Interstate Highway to have a reduced speed limit. US 131 in Grand Rapids is one of the only non-Interstate urban freeways in Michigan with a {{convert|70|mph}} speed limit, which was raised from {{convert|55|mph}} since 2013. Furthermore, speed limits in smaller cities, such as [[Kalamazoo, Michigan|Kalamazoo]], [[Ann Arbor, Michigan|Ann Arbor]], and [[Lansing, Michigan|Lansing]] (the state capital) remain at {{cvt|70|mph}}.
The default speed on all other highways, whether two or four lanes, is {{cvt|55|mph}}. However, Michigan permits speed limits of up to {{cvt|65|mph}} after a safety study concludes the higher limit is safe to implement. Until 2016, this provision only applied to four-lane divided non-limited access highways. A {{convert|20|mile|adj=on}} stretch of [[U.S. Route 127 in Michigan|US 127]] between [[St. Johns, Michigan|St. Johns]] and [[Ithaca, Michigan|Ithaca]] was posted at {{cvt|65|mph}}, as a compromise to allow a freer flow of traffic due to insufficient funds to improve the section to freeway standards. The speed limit on [[U.S. Route 2 in Michigan|US 2]] between [[Rapid River, Michigan|Rapid River]] and [[Gladstone, Michigan|Gladstone]] in the [[Upper Peninsula]] was also raised to {{cvt|65|mph}}. In Summer 2017 Speed limits began increasing to 65 mph on several select two-lane roads in both the Lower and Upper Peninsulas of Michigan, including US 2 from St. Ignace to Rapid River and M-28 from I-75 to Munising.
==Midway Atoll== The speed limit in [[Midway Atoll]] is 15 mph (24 km/h).<ref>https://www.govregs.com/regulations/expand/title50_chapterI_part38_subpartC_section38.13 Midway Atoll Code. Retrieved 8 January 2018.</ref>
==Minnesota== A 70 mph speed limit is only allowed on [[Minnesota]]'s [[Interstate Highway System|Interstates]] outside of urban areas. A speed limit of 55 mph is typically used in urban areas where a higher speed limit might be used, but traffic congestion or other reasons require a lower speed limit. Examples include [[Interstate 94 in Minnesota|I-94]], [[Interstate 35W (Minnesota)|I-35W]] and [[Interstate 35E (Minnesota)|I-35E]] in and around [[Minneapolis]], [[Moorhead, Minnesota|Moorhead]] and [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]]. 35E goes down to a speed limit of 45 mph in some areas of Saint Paul. A speed limit of 60 mph is typically used in suburban areas such as [[Interstate 494|I-494]] and [[Interstate 694|I-694]] loops in the Twin Cities metro area.
Non-Interstate [[divided highway]]s (both freeways and [[Limited-access road|expressways]]) have speed limits of 65 mph in rural areas and up to 60 mph in urban or suburban areas (NOTE: some non-interstate divided highways have gotten speed limit increases in November 2017 such as US Route 169 in the Twin Cities Metropolitan area). Rural two lane State and US highways in Minnesota have a default speed limits of 55 mph although several 60 mph speed limits have been posted after a traffic and engineering study that will continue until 2019. County roads have speed limits of up to 55 mph for 2 lanes and 60 for divided sections.
==Mississippi== A speed limit of 70 mph is only allowed on [[Mississippi]]'s rural freeways; only the [[Interstate Highway|Interstates]] (except [[Interstate 110 (Mississippi)|I-110]]), [[U.S. Highway 78]], [[Mississippi Highway 304]], and a portion of [[U.S. Highway 82]] have speed limits of 70 mph, with these lengths making up approximately 86% of the state's freeway mileage.
A speed limit of 65 mph is typically used on the state's four-lane divided highways, which include parts of the following roadways: * [[U.S. Route 45]] / [[U.S. Route 45 Alternate]] * [[U.S. Route 49]] / [[U.S. Route 49W]] * [[U.S. Route 61]] * [[U.S. Route 72]] * [[U.S. Route 82]] * [[U.S. Route 84]] * [[U.S. Route 90]] * [[U.S. Route 98]] * [[U.S. Route 278]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 15|MS 15]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 19|MS 19]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 25|MS 25]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 39|MS 39]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 57|MS 57]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 63|MS 63]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 67|MS 67]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 302|MS 302]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 605|MS 605]] * [[Mississippi State Highway 607|MS 607]]
A speed limit of 60 mph is typically used in urban areas where a higher speed limit might be used, but traffic or geometric conditions constitute a lower speed limit, including the following areas: * [[Interstate 20]] in [[Vicksburg, Mississippi|Vicksburg]], from [[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]] to [[Pearl, Mississippi|Pearl]], and [[Meridian, Mississippi|Meridian]] * [[Interstate 55]] from Jackson to [[Ridgeland, Mississippi|Ridgeland]] * [[Interstate 59]] in [[Laurel, Mississippi|Laurel]] and Meridian * [[U.S. Route 61]] in [[Tunica Resorts, Mississippi|Tunica Resorts]] * [[U.S. Route 78]] in [[New Albany, Mississippi|New Albany]] * [[U.S. Route 82]] in [[Columbus, Mississippi|Columbus]]
House Bill 3, passed during the 2008 First Extraordinary Session of the state legislature, permits speed limits up to {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on toll roads in the state; however, {{As of|2016|lc=on}}, no such road has been constructed.<ref>[http://billstatus.ls.state.ms.us/documents/20081E/html/HB/0001-0099/HB0003SG.htm HB 3 (As Sent to Governor)]. Billstatus.ls.state.ms.us.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.yourmechanic.com/article/mississippi-speed-limits-laws-and-fines-by-valerie-mellema|title=Mississippi Speed Limits, Laws, and Fines {{!}} YourMechanic Advice|website=www.yourmechanic.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref>
Mississippi has a minimum speed of 30 mph on four-lane [[United States Numbered Highways|U.S. highways]] when no hazard exists. Strangely, there is no law for the minimum speed of the state's growing number of four-lane state highways. The minimum is 40 mph on Interstate Highways and on four-lane U.S. designated highways that have a 70 mph speed limit.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://198.187.128.12/mississippi/lpext.dll?f=templates&fn=fs-main.htm&2.0# |title=Mississippi Code §63-3-509 |access-date=August 13, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070308095040/http://198.187.128.12/mississippi/lpext.dll?f=templates&fn=fs-main.htm&2.0# |archive-date=March 8, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2004, Mississippi posted minimum speed limits (40 mph) on all rural Interstates, but this minimum speed limit was already state law before then.
==Missouri== Statutory speed limits in [[Missouri]] are as follows: * Interstate highways and freeways in rural areas: 70 mph * Expressways in rural areas: 65 mph (notable exceptions being the US 54 & US 63 Expressways to the north of Jefferson City, which are at-grade expressways with a 70 mph speed limit) * Interstates, freeways, and expressways in urban areas: 60 mph * Other numbered state-maintained rural highways: 60 mph * State lettered highways: 55 mph
Freeways are defined as: "a limited access divided highway of at least ten miles in length with four or more lanes which is not part of the federal interstate system of highways which does not have any crossovers or accesses from streets, roads or other highways at the same grade level as such divided highway within such ten miles of divided highway."
Expressways are defined as: "a divided highway of at least ten miles in length with four or more lanes which is not part of the federal interstate system of highways which has crossovers or accesses from streets, roads or other highways at the same grade level as such divided highway."
Urban Areas are defined as: "an area of fifty thousand population at a density at or greater than one thousand persons per square mile".
The highways and transportation commission may raise or lower the speed limit on these highways, but no speed limit may be set above 70 mph on a numbered highway and 60 mph on a lettered highway.<ref>[http://www.moga.mo.gov/statutes/C300-399/3040000010.HTM Missouri Revised Statutes §304-010]. Moga.mo.gov (August 28, 2012).</ref>
Interstate highways have minimum speed limits of 40 mph. There have been talks of 75 mph being enforced on Interstate highways, but a bill allowing the law has yet to be enforced.<ref>[http://www.moga.mo.gov/statutes/C300-399/3040000011.HTM Missouri Revised Statutes §304-011]. Moga.mo.gov (August 28, 2012).</ref>
===Variable speed limits=== Missouri concluded a two-year experiment with [[variable speed limit]]s along [[Interstate 270 (Illinois-Missouri)|I-270]] around [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]]. Digital [[traffic sign|signs]] had been erected along the freeway as well as additional signs alerting drivers about the use of variable speed limits. The limits will vary between 40 and 60 miles per hour, depending on traffic conditions, and could change by up to 5 mph every 5 minutes. These speed limits, as of January 2012, are now posted as "Advisory Speed Limits".<ref>{{cite web |title=Dickerson Oxton |url=http://www.dickersonoxton.com/missouri-accidents-county-2013/ |publisher=Missouri Motor Vehicle Accidents by County in 2013.}}</ref>
During the closure and major rebuild of [[Interstate 64 in Missouri|I-64]] in St. Louis, an additional lane was added to [[Interstate 44 in Missouri|I-44]] and [[Interstate 70 in Missouri|I-70]], and the speed limit was thus reduced to 55 mph on those roads within the St. Louis County and City. The I-64 construction has been completed, and the extra lanes were removed in 2010. In October 2010, the speed limit was restored to 60 mph on both I-44 and I-70.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmov.com/news/local/MoDOT-to-increase-speed-limit-on-I-44-in-St-Louis-County-105691118.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101027132320/http://www.kmov.com/news/local/MoDOT-to-increase-speed-limit-on-I-44-in-St-Louis-County-105691118.html |archivedate=October 27, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}. KMOV (October 25, 2010).</ref>
===Exceptions to the statutory limits=== Most two-lane roads with shoulders have a 60 mph speed limit in Missouri. Two-lane roads without shoulders are usually, but not always, limited to 55 mph. However, the following two-lane highways have a 65 mph speed limit when bypassing or outside of incorporated areas. * [[U.S. Route 54|US-54]] from [[El Dorado Springs, Missouri|El Dorado Springs]] west to the [[Kansas]] state line; from the [[Missouri Route 73|MO-73]] intersection southwest of [[Macks Creek, Missouri|Macks Creek]] to just west of the [[Niangua River]] bridge; and also along the [[Mexico, Missouri|Mexico]] bypass. * [[U.S. Route 63|US-63]] from [[Vienna, Missouri|Vienna]] south to [[Thayer, Missouri|Thayer]], near the [[Arkansas]] state line. Some of this route has three lanes, with the passing lane alternating between northbound and southbound traffic. * [[Missouri Route 5|MO-5]] between [[Camdenton, Missouri|Camdenton]] and [[Lebanon, Missouri|Lebanon]]. This road has three lanes, with the passing lane alternating between northbound and southbound traffic. * [[Missouri Route 43|MO-43]] from US-54 south to [[Joplin, Missouri|Joplin]] * [[Missouri Route 96|MO-96]] from I-44 west to [[Carthage, Missouri|Carthage]]
Most rural expressways have a 65 mph speed limit, but the following have a 70 mph speed limit. * [[U.S. Route 54|US-54]] from the south end of the [[Mexico, Missouri|Mexico]] bypass to the Route W interchange just across the [[Missouri River]] from [[Jefferson City, Missouri|Jefferson City]], with the exception of the I-70 interchange area at Kingdom City, which is 45 mph. US-54 also has a 70 mph speed limit from Fall Hill Road in [[Cole County, Missouri|Cole County]] to just north of the Business Route 54 intersection in [[Lake Ozark, Missouri|Lake Ozark]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.connectmidmissouri.com/news/story.aspx?id=473645#.UV4ZK5OG16g|publisher=KRGC|date=June 22, 2010|accessdate=March 19, 2017|last=Miller|first=Kermit|title=Speed limit lowered on Highway 54}}</ref> * [[U.S. Route 63|US-63]] from the south end of the [[Kirksville, Missouri|Kirksville]] bypass to US-54 north of [[Jefferson City, Missouri|Jefferson City]], with the exception of the section through [[Columbia, Missouri|Columbia]] from Route B to Route AC, which is 65 mph.<ref>[http://tmn.truman.edu/theindex/2013/01/16/modot-increase-route-63-speed-limit/] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814041632/http://tmn.truman.edu/theindex/2013/01/16/modot-increase-route-63-speed-limit/# |date=August 14, 2014 }} Truman State University Index (January 16, 2013)</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/news/local/state-cuts-speed-on-highway/article_4a8be01c-b958-5b1f-be5d-924cf8f8d893.html|publisher=Columbia Tribune|date=April 11, 2010|accessdate=March 19, 2017|last=David|first=Brennan|title=Sate cuts speed on highway}}</ref> * [[Missouri Route 7|MO-7]] from [[Interstate 49 in Missouri|I-49]] to just west of [[Clinton, Missouri|Clinton]]. * The [[U.S. Route 71 in Missouri|US-71]] expressway from [[Carthage, Missouri|Carthage]] to [[Harrisonville, Missouri|Harrisonville]] had a 70 mph limit before it was upgraded to [[Interstate 49 in Missouri|I-49]].
* MO-360 and US 160 outside of the Springfield, Missouri border has an upgraded speed limit of 70 MPH from the speed limit of 60 MPH
Most Missouri [[Missouri supplemental route|lettered highways]] are 55 mph, and in densely populated areas they can be less. There are several that have a speed limit of 60 mph, though. * [[Missouri Route M (Jefferson County)|Route M]] in Jefferson County is an expressway for most of its length, and most of the highway has a speed limit of 60 mph. * Route A in Jefferson County, an upgraded two lane road with shoulders, has a 60 mph speed limit. Route A travels between [[Hillsboro, Missouri|Hillsboro]] and [[Festus, Missouri|Festus]]. *Route B in Boone County is mostly an upgraded two lane road with shoulders. As such, it has a 60 mph speed limit from just north of [[Columbia, MO|Columbia]] to the end of the upgraded section 1 mile south of [[Hallsville, Missouri|Hallsville]]. *Route B in Cole County is a four-lane divided highway from [[US Route 54|US 54]] to Lorenzo Greene Dr in [[Jefferson City, Missouri|Jefferson City]], and is an upgraded two-lane highway with shoulders for the rest of the way south to [[Wardsville, Missouri|Wardsville]]. Both sections have a 60 mph speed limit. *Route C in Cole County is an upgraded two-lane highway with shoulders, and has a 60 mph speed limit from just west of [[Jefferson City, Missouri|Jefferson City]] to just east of [[Russellville, Missouri|Russellville]]. *Route A in Osage County follows the former routing of [[US Route 50 in Missouri|US Route 50]] from its intersection with modern-day US 50 to [[Loose Creek, Missouri|Loose Creek]]. Since the roadway is designed to the same standards as a major highway, the speed limit is 60 on that stretch of road.
In the urban areas of: [[St. Louis]], [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], [[Columbia, Missouri|Columbia]], [[St. Joseph, Missouri|St. Joseph]], and [[Springfield, Missouri|Springfield]], the speed limit typically drops to 60 mph on Interstates and freeways. In addition, on I-44 in [[Rolla, Missouri|Rolla]] the speed limit is reduced to 60 mph from just west of Exit 184 to Exit 186 because of a substandard design.
Freeway speed limits in urban areas can be as low as 45 or 50 mph in a few very short sections in downtown Kansas City and St. Louis, or as high as 65 mph in the outer portions of the St. Louis, Kansas City and St. Joseph areas. The [[Cape Girardeau, Missouri|Cape Girardeau]] and [[Joplin, Missouri|Joplin]] areas have no reduced freeway speed limits, and I-435 around [[Kansas City metropolitan area|Kansas City]] has a 70 mph limit from I-35 in [[Claycomo, Missouri|Claycomo]] to the Kansas State Line around the northern and western part of the metro area.
[[Interstate 29|I-29]] in Kansas City has a limit of 70 mph north of Barry Road in Platte County to south of Highway 169 in Buchanan County where the limit drops to 65 mph. North of Frederick Road in Buchanan County the limit returns to 70 mph until the [[Iowa]] state line.
==Montana==<!-- This section is linked from [[Speed ~]] --> As of October 1, 2015, the maximum speed limit in Montana is 80 mph. On May 5, 2015, a bill to increase Montana's rural interstate highway speed limit to 80 mph was signed into law by Governor [[Steve Bullock (Montana politician)|Steve Bullock]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://helenair.com/news/politics/updated-bullock-signs-higher-mph-interstate-speed-limit-into-law/article_f47fc9aa-2fee-5459-80a1-b252331380a3.html |title=Bullock signs higher 80 mph interstate speed limit into law |work=Helena Independent Record |date=May 5, 2015 |accessdate=May 6, 2015 |author=Dennison, Mike}}</ref>
===Reasonable and prudent=== [[File:MONTANA-PR.svg|thumb|right|250px|Typical speed limit sign that one would see at the Montana state line from December 1995 to June 1999]]
In the years before the 1974 [[National Maximum Speed Law#1974—55 mph National Speed Limit|national 55 mph limit]], and for three years after the [[National Maximum Speed Law#1995—Repeal of federal limits|1995 repeal of the increased 65 mph limit]], [[Montana]] had a non-numeric "reasonable and prudent" speed limit during the daytime on most rural roads. Montana Code Annotated (MCA) Section 61-8-303 said "A person ... shall drive the vehicle ... at a rate of speed no greater than is reasonable and proper under the conditions existing at the point of operation ... so as not to unduly or unreasonably endanger the life, limb, property, or other rights of a person entitled to the use of the street or highway."
Montana law also specified a few numeric limits: a night speed limit, usually 55 or 65 mph (89–105 km/h), depending on road type; 25 mph (40 km/h) in urban districts and 35 mph (56 km/h) in construction zones.
The phrase "reasonable and prudent" is found in the language of most state speed laws. This allows prosecution under non-ideal conditions such as rain or snow when the speed limit would be imprudently fast.
===No speed limit=== On March 10, 1996,<ref>[http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?court=MT&vol=97&invol=486 FindLaw for Legal Professionals – Case Law, Federal and State Resources, Forms, and Code]. Caselaw.lp.findlaw.com.</ref> a Montana [[highway patrol|patrolman]] issued a [[traffic ticket|speeding ticket]] to a driver traveling at 85 mph (136 km/h) on a stretch of [[Montana Highway 200|State Highway 200]]. The 50‑year‑old driver (Rudy Stanko) was operating a 1996 [[Chevrolet Camaro]] with less than 10,000 miles (16,093 km) on the [[odometer]].<!-- The preceding text is relevant because newness of the vehicle and age-implied competence of driver are relevant. Part of reasonable and prudent is whether the vehicle and driver can handle the speed. --> Although the officer gave no opinion as to what would have been a reasonable speed, the driver was convicted. The driver appealed to the [[Montana Supreme Court]]. The Court reversed the conviction in case No. 97-486 on December 23, 1998; it held that a law requiring drivers to drive at a non-numerical "reasonable and proper" speed "is so [[Void for vagueness|vague]] that it violates the [[Due Process]] Clause ... of the [[Montana Constitution]]".
Effective May 28, 1999, as a result of that decision, the [[Montana State Government|Montana Legislature]] established a speed limit of 75 mph.<ref>[http://www.mdt.mt.gov/travinfo/speed_limit.shtml Official Montana Department of Transportation site]. Mdt.mt.gov (May 28, 1999).</ref> * Montana's US, State, and even Secondary roads have speed limits posted 70 mph/night:65; truck:60/night:55. Seven years later, a research study conducted by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a long-time advocate of the federal National Maximum Speed Law, showed Montana's 75 mph speed limit on rural Interstates was well received by motorists; traffic speed measurements taken by IIHS showed 76 percent of cars in compliance with 75 mph on those roads. IIHS also found large trucks subject to Montana's unchanged 65 mph speed limit for large trucks on rural Interstates slowed down dramatically, from a mean speed of 70 mph in 1996 to 65 mph in 2006, with the 85th percentile large truck speed dropping 11 mph, from 79 mph in 1996 to 68 mph in 2006.<ref>Retting, Richard, and Yeoh, Eric, 2008. "Traffic Speeds on Interstates and Freeways 10 Years After Repeal of National Maximum Speed Limit." Traffic Injury Prevention 9: 119-124, p. 122, Table II. {{ISSN|1538-9588}}.</ref>
===75 and 80 mph speed limits=== Despite this reversal, Montana's then-governor, [[Marc Racicot]], did not convene an emergency session of the legislature. Montana technically had no speed limit whatsoever until June 1999, after the Montana legislature met in regular session and enacted a new law. The law's practical effect was to require numeric speed limits on all roads and disallow any speed limit higher than 75 mph (121 km/h).
Montana law still contains a section that says "a person shall operate a vehicle in a careful and prudent manner and at a reduced rate of speed no greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions existing at the point of operation, taking into account the amount and character of [[traffic congestion|traffic]], [[driver visibility|visibility]], weather, and roadway conditions." However, this is a standard clause that appears in other state traffic codes and has the practical effect of requiring a speed lower than the speed limit where a lower speed is necessary to maintain a reasonable and prudent road manner.
Montana also has limited sections of night speed limits.<ref name="MT Night">{{cite web |title=61-8-303(1)(b) - Speed restrictions |url=https://leg.mt.gov/bills/mca/title_0610/chapter_0080/part_0030/section_0030/0610-0080-0030-0030.html |website=Montana Code Annotated |publisher=[[State of Montana]] |accessdate=4 July 2018 |quote=the speed limit for vehicles traveling...on any other public highway of this state is 70 miles an hour during the '''daytime''' and 65 miles an hour during the '''nighttime'''}}</ref> Other speed limits in Montana are 15-35 mph in a school zone,<ref>http://leg.mt.gov/bills/mca/61/8/61-8-310.htm</ref> 30 mph in a residential district, 35-45 mph on boulevards, 55 mph on traffic-light highways, 65-70 mph on rural divided 4-lane highways, and 55-70 mph on rural 2-lane undivided highways.
==Nebraska== The maximum speed limit in Nebraska is 75 mph on rural Interstate highways.
